text: Radenac () is a commune in the Morbihan department in Brittany in north- western France. ==Geography== The Ével has its source in the commune. ==People== Cyclist Jean Robic, who won the Tour de France in 1947, spent his childhood in Radenac, where his father owned the local cycle shop. In honour of his great achievement, the commune renamed the street where his home was after him. ==Population== Inhabitants of Radenac are called Radenacois. ==Twin towns== Radenac is twinned with a small village of Radnage in Buckinghamshire . ==Monuments== * The fountain of St Armel (circa 1000) * The fountain of St Fiacre (17th century) * The chapelle St Fiacre (construction 1390 to 1514). ==See also== *Communes of the Morbihan department ==References== * Mayors of Morbihan Association * INSEE commune file ==External links== *French Ministry of Culture list for Radenac Category:Communes of Morbihan
title: Radenac
